Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Epidemiology meets symbiosis: modeling symbiont spread through multi-host communities
Award.AbstractNarration:
Most new infectious diseases in humans are zoonotic, which means the pathogens that cause these diseases originate in wild and domestic animals and then spread to humans. Many pathogens that infect livestock and wildlife species are also found in other species. Mathematical models that describe pathogen transmission within single wildlife host species (e.g., rabies transmission within bat populations) and between different host species (e.g., rabies transmission between bats and skunks) are critical tools for understanding and predicting disease outbreaks in humans, livestock, and wildlife. In addition to being used to understand the spread of pathogens among hosts, these same models can be used to understand the spread of beneficial symbionts (small organisms such as bacteria that live in much larger hosts) that help rather than harm the host. However, the fundamental assumptions that underlie these mathematical models are rarely tested, because observing animal contact rates and spread of disease in nature is difficult. This research will use a system of hosts and their symbionts to test assumptions on which the existing models are built, and will quantify how well those models can predict disease transmission in wildlife populations. The results of this research will ultimately lead to mathematical models that are better at predicting symbiont transmission.

Wildlife population densities often vary across space and time. Classic epidemiological models use one of two mechanistic transmission functions to describe the relationship between host density and pathogen transmission rates. The first assumes that animal contact rates and thus transmission rates increase linearly with host density (density-dependent transmission), and the second assumes that animal contact rates and transmission rates are not affected by host density (frequency-dependent transmission). However, nonlinear relationships that fall somewhere between those extremes may be more appropriate in many host-symbiont systems. Using an experimentally tractable multi-host system - symbiotic annelid worms living on freshwater snails - this research will: (1) empirically quantify the relationship between host density and both intra- and inter-specific host contact rates, and (2) use the resulting model to make and test predictions regarding symbiont transmission dynamics in single and multi-host host communities at broad spatial and temporal scales in natural systems. Critical evaluation of fundamental model assumptions and the resulting model predictions will lead to better predictive models of symbiont transmission.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Infectious diseases cause substantial morbidity and mortality in humans, our domesticated plants and animals, and wildlife species, and thus improving our abilities to understand, predict, and control how pathogens spread through populations are priorities for advancing national and global health. For decades, mathematical models have served as critical tools for these endeavors. These same models can also be used to describe and predict the spread of beneficial symbionts, like the symbiotic bacteria that help us to digest our food. We systematically reviewed scientific studies published in the 21st century that included epidemiological mathematical models representing parasitic or beneficial symbiont transmission within a single species (e.g., Ebola transmission within a bat colony) or between host species (e.g., Ebola transmission from bats to gorillas). We found that  researchers in fields as diverse as public health, theoretical ecology, and conservation medicine still predominantly rely on an epidemiological model structure that was proposed in the early 1900s. Those early models specifically assumed that as the number of human or non-human animal hosts living in an area increases, the rate of symbiont transmission amongst hosts also increases in a linear or proportional fashion. But we found surprisingly few studies that had experimentally tested this common assumption, and the existing experiments usually found that alternative, nonlinear assumptions provided better descriptions of symbiont transmission. This mismatch between experimental results and common modeling practices suggests that it is time to revisit and revise our critical epidemiological tools, especially for use with wildlife populations that have variable host population densities.  

We performed a series of experiments in a tractable wildlife system to better understand how transmission changes with wildlife host density. We found that in the laboratory, contacts between snails within one species and between different snail species increased nonlinearly with snail host density, similar to the majority of prior experiments found in our literature review. We also found that symbiont transmission within a snail species increased nonlinearly with host snail density in natural ponds. Snail contacts and symbiont transmission reached an upper limit at high snail density because each snail contact takes a few minutes, and during that time, snails miss out on opportunities for other contacts. This mechanism that creates an upper limit for contact rates is already well known in studies regarding interactions between predators and prey, and it might be broadly applicable to all epidemiological models that describe direct-contact symbiont transmission amongst animals. Given this potential generality, we expect that our revised assumptions will stimulate future critical evaluation of epidemiological models and their predictions, which will lead to better predictive models of symbiont transmission.   

This work provided a graduate student from an under-represented group with professional training, which included opportunities to learn new modeling skills and travel to four national conferences to disseminate research results. The graduate student co-PI graduated successfully in May 2017 and her dissertation, which included this work, received Virginia Tech’s Outstanding STEM Dissertation Award. Two undergraduate students also received training in conducting ecological research through this project, including presenting their results at regional conferences and co-authoring peer-reviewed publications. Finally, the project resulted in development of a hands-on, inquiry-based learning module related to aquatic snails, which achieved several of the Virginia Standards of Learning for K-5 students. This educational outreach module reached 120 fifth grade students through Virginia’s Kindergarten-2-College (K2C) program.
